Row.Text: Allows embassies to be established at other civilization's capitals.
The Religion system is turned off in this game. No Faith earned. Pantheons and Religions may not be founded.
{1_current}/{2_needed}[NEWLINE]Fremskridt til en ny admiral er baseret på ERFARING draget fra søslag.
{1_current}/{2_needed}[NEWLINE]Fremskridt til en ny general er baseret på ERFARING draget fra landslag.
Mangler minimum {1_MinFaith} [ICON_PEACE] Tro til en ny Profet
Antal af religioner der kan grundlægges: {1_NumAvailReligions}
Mangler {1_NumFaith} [ICON_PEACE] Tro til at skabe en Mytologi
For sent at skabe en Mytologi
Spionen vil forsøge at foretage et statskup for at blive allieret med bystaten. Bystaten skal allerede være allieret med en anden civilisation.

{1_SpyRank} {2_SpyName} vil forsøge et statskup i {3_CityName}, ved at bringe en gruppe loyale til os til magten. Den førende {4_CivShortDesc} faktion vil blive bortvist og deres indflydelse reduceret.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Denne opgave har en {5_PERCENT}% succesrate.[ENDCOLOR] Hvis succesfuld, bliver du allieret med {6_CityName} og {7_CivShortDesc} vil have deres indflydelse droppet. Hvis du fejler, vil din spion blive dræbt i forsøget og din indflydelse med {8_CityName} vil falde.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Skal {9_SpyRank} {10_SpyName} forsøge et kup i {11_CityName}?
Vælg en Grundlæggerdogme (bonus til grundlæggerens civilisation).
Vælg en Troendes Dogme (bonus til hver troende by).
Tilgængelig senere når Religion er forbedret.
Er du sikker på du vil grundlægge {1_ReligionName}?
Er du klar til at forbedre {1_ReligionName}?
Antallet af stemmer hver spiller er prognostieret i det næste FN-valg. De reelle stemmer vil varierer baseret på begivenheder der finder sted mellem nu og valget.

In the previous election, {@1_CivName} received {2_NumVotesFromCivs} votes from Civilizations. This may change in the upcoming election based on international relations. Civilizations will vote for the other Civilization they have the best relations with.

{@1_CivName} will get {2_NumVotesFromMinorCivs} votes from City-States, if City-State relations remain the same as they are now. City-States will vote for the Civilization that most recently liberated them, or their current ally if there is no liberator.
{@1_CivName} gets 1 vote from building the UN.
In the previous election, the number of votes received from other Civilizations.
In the last UN election, {@1_CivName} received votes from the Civilizations that had the best relations with them:
In the previous election, which Civilization was voted for. (Cannot vote for self.)
{@1_VotingCivName} voted for {@2_RecipientCivName} in the last election, since they had the best relations.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Current mood of {@1_VotingCivName} towards you: {@3_MoodTowardsYou}
Videnskabssystemet er slået fra i dette scenarie. Ingen nye teknologier vil blive opnået.
Glædesystemet er slået fra i dette scenarie. Guldaldre vil ikke forekomme. Alle konsekvenser af vrede er også slået fra.
The Social Policy system is off in this scenario. No new policies will be gained, although culture will still act to expand city borders.

You have achieved victory through mastery of Science! You have conquered the mysteries of nature and led your people on a voyage to a brave new world! Your triumph will be remembered as long as the stars burn in the night sky!
The world has been convulsed by war. Many great and powerful civilizations have fallen, but you have survived - and emerged victorious! The world will long remember your glorious triumph!

You have achieved victory through the awesome power of your Culture. Your civilization's greatness - the magnificence of its monuments and the power of its artists - have astounded the world! Poets will honor you for as long as beauty brings gladness to a weary heart.

You have triumphed over your foes through the art of Diplomacy! Your cunning and wisdom have earned you great friends - and divided and sown confusion among your enemies! Forever will you be remembered as the leader who brought peace to a weary world!
The world has been convulsed by war. Many great and powerful civilizations have fallen, but you have survived - and emerged victorious! The world will long remember your glorious triumph!
You have been defeated. Your civilization has been overwhelmed by its many foes. But your people do not despair, for they know that one day you shall return - and lead them forward to victory!

Many years have passed since the rise of your great and powerful civilization. Unfortunately, your time has come to an end, but your people do not despair, for they know that one day you shall return - and lead them forward to victory!
You have not yet completed any games.
You have achieved the level of {1_GreatLeader}

Total cost of maintaining Units you own (military and civilian). The cost for each is currently {1_Num} [ICON_GOLD], which increases with the total number and over time ({2_Num} Units Total).
You own {1_NumUnits} {1_NumUnits: plural 1?unit; other?units;} which {1_NumUnits: plural 1?does not; other?do not;} require maintenance.
Total cost of maintaining Buildings you own.
This would be the full cost on a higher difficulty level.
You pay {1_Num}% of the normal cost because of the game's current difficulty level.
Total cost of maintaining Roads and Railroads you have built, or are responsible for. Roads cost 1 [ICON_GOLD] Gold per turn, and RRs cost 2 [ICON_GOLD].
Because of the game's current difficulty level, they produce {1_Num}% less than usual.
Because of the game's current map size, they produce {1_Num}% less than usual.
Because of your Policies, [ICON_CITIZEN] Citizens in your Capital produce {1_Num}% the usual amount.
Because of your civilization's traits, they produce {1_Num}% the usual amount.
Because of bonuses your empire has earned, they produce {1_Num}% the usual amount.
Because of bonuses your empire has earned, Specialist citizens produce half the normal [ICON_HAPPINESS_4] Unhappiness.
Every [ICON_CITIZEN] Citizen in a (non-occupied) City produces 1 [ICON_HAPPINESS_4] Unhappiness
Every [ICON_CITIZEN] Citizen in an [ICON_OCCUPIED] Occupied City produces 1.34 [ICON_HAPPINESS_4] Unhappiness
The text "{1_stringEntered}" could not be found.
[NEWLINE][TAB][TAB]"Such is the patriot's boast, where'er we roam, His first, best country ever is, at home."[NEWLINE][TAB][TAB] - Oliver Goldsmith[NEWLINE][TAB]
You are currently running Civilization V v.1.0.

Welcome to the Civilopedia! Here you will find detailed descriptions of all aspects of the game. Use the "Search" field to search for articles on any specific subject. Clicking on the tabs on the top edge of the screen will take you to the various major sections of the Civilopedia. The Navigation Bar on the left side of the screen will display the various entries within a section. Click on an entry to go directly there.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]In the upper left-hand portion of the screen you will find the forward and back buttons which will help you navigate between pages. Click on the "X" on the upper right portion of the screen to return to the game.

Civilization V examines all of human history - from the deep past to the day after tomorrow. The "Game Concepts" portion of the Civilopedia explains some of the more important parts of the game - how to build and manage cities, how to fight wars, how to research technology, and so forth. The left Navigation Bar displays the major concepts; click on an entry to see the subsections within the concepts.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]You can read all of the Game Concepts from start to finish, if you're the author's mom, but for everyone else we recommend that you start a game and check them out when you need them in play. If we've done our jobs right the in-game Tutorial will be all you need to do to understand how to navigate the early game.

Technology is really important to the success or failure of your civilization. There are over 70 techs in the game, and each provides you with a significant advantage in play. Some techs allow you to construct cool new buildings and wonders, others increase the output from your fields and mines, and others still let you build railroads, or advanced weaponry.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]It's critically important that your civ remains competitive in the technology race. If you get behind more than a step or two, you'll find yourself facing the same dilemma as the Aztecs, facing Spanish muskets and cannon with obsidian swords and slings. And as history tells us, the side with the advanced technology always wins those encounters.

Units represent the more mobile aspects of your civilization, the workers who till the fields, the settlers who build new cities, the Great People who can singlehandedly change the course of a country through their genius or creativity. And of course units also represent your civ's military.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Most units are built in your cities. Use them wisely. Always make sure that you have enough combat units to accomplish the military task at hand and to defend your cities, but don't overbuild, or the cost of supporting them will beggar your civ. Upgrade your military units when you can, but don't be shy about destroying them if you're overburdened. Similarly, have enough workers to handle the job, but they are expensive to maintain, so keep an eye on your finances.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Whatever you do, early in the game send out units to explore the world! If you don't know what's going on in the world around you, you're liable to face some really ugly and possibly fatal surprises from greedy neighbors!

Your units earn promotions through combat, and also from being constructed in cities with Barracks or other military buildings. Promotions can dramatically improve a unit's combat ability or increase its movement or its healing rate. A unit with a lot of promotions is extremely valuable - use them wisely in battle and always upgrade them when possible.

Buildings can dramatically improve a city's wealth, population, defenses, or productivity. Certain buildings will improve the quality of some military units constructed there, while others will allow a coastal city to harvest food from the oceans.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]It's important to construct buildings. If your civilization is heavily involved in combat, the temptation may be to focus all of your production on military units, but if you pursue this pathway for too long, your cities may become inferior to other civs' better-developed cities, putting you at a significant disadvantage as the game progresses.

Wonders are the remarkable, one-of-a-kind buildings that ensure that a civilization will be remembered throughout all of history. Wonders engage the mind and lift the spirits.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]The Pyramids, Notre Dame Cathedral, and Stonehenge are examples of wonders. Wonders require much time and energy from your cities to construct, but once completed, they provide your civilization with many benefits.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]There are three basic types of wonders: World Wonders, National Wonders and Project Wonders. Only one copy of a World Wonder may be constructed anywhere in the world in a given game. National Wonders are less exclusive: each nation may construct one (but only one) copy of a National Wonder.

Social Policies represent the way that you choose to govern your people. Will you be an authoritarian ruler, sacrificing a little freedom for discipline and increased productivity? Will you organize your civilization to have a strong military, or will you concentrate their efforts on expanding culture? Will you have a monarchy, or a democracy?[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Social policies have concrete effects in play. Some may increase your cities' production, while others might generate more wealth, and still others might create more effective military units. [NEWLINE] [NEWLINE]There are no right or wrong social policy choices in the game. One policy may be better for a given circumstance than another (say, if you're surrounded by belligerent civs you may want to take a different path than if you're relatively isolated), and one may better suit your play style. Try them out and see.

Time and again throughout history, there have arisen men and women who have profoundly changed the world around them - artists, scientists, generals, merchants and others, whose genius sets them head and shoulders above the rest. In this game such visionaries are called "Great People."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]There are five different kinds of great people in the game: Great Merchants, Great Artists, Great Scientists, Great Engineers, and Great Generals. Each has a special ability.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Your civilization acquires Great People by constructing certain buildings and wonders, and then staffing them with "specialists", citizens from your cities who have given up working in the field or the mines. While specialists do not work city tiles, they do greatly speed the arrival of Great People. Balancing the need for food and the desire for Great People is an important challenge of city management.

There are a wide variety of Civilizations and leaders to choose from in the game. Each has its own special units, buildings and/or abilities - America has the Minuteman and the B-17 Bomber, Rome has the Legion and the Ballista, and Russia has the Cossack and the Krepost. Learning to manage each Civilization's strengths and weaknesses is one of the most fun aspects of play and makes every game different. If you play Egypt using the exact same strategy as you use when playing India, you may be missing the point.

City-States represent the many smaller civilizations that occupy the world. City-States are just that: states centered upon a city. They cannot build settlers and thus cannot create new cities (their territory can expand, however, but it will never contain more than one city). The exception to this is through conquest. City-States at war are capable of capturing enemy cities.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]If you befriend a City-State, it may provide you with food, culture, or even military units. If you attack a City-State, you may capture a new city to add to your mighty empire. (This might cause the other city-states to declare war on you, so do so with care.)

In Civilization V, the world is made up of hexagonally-shaped "tiles" (also occasionally known as hexes and spaces). These tiles come in a variety of "terrain types" - desert, plains, grassland, hills and so forth - and many also include "features" like forests and jungle. These elements help to determine the tile's usefulness to a nearby city as well as how easy or difficult it is to move through the tile. Also, a tile's terrain and features may have important effects upon any combat occurring there.

Features are elements of terrain or vegetation that appear in a hex, atop the hex's terrain. (A grassland hex might have forest or marsh on it as well, for example.) Features modify a hex's productivity and might also alter the amount of "movement points" (MP) a unit expends when entering the hex. Features may also provide defensive combat bonuses or penalties to a unit occupying the hex.

The world is filled with various "resources" that can aid in a civilization's growth and development. These include cattle, wheat, coal, iron, whales, and oil. During a game, you will want to build your cities near to resources so that they can take advantage of the resources' bonuses. Some resources - gold and fish, for example - are visible at the start of a game, while others - like aluminum, oil, and uranium - are hidden until your Civilization has mastered the appropriate technology.

During a game, you will create "workers" - non-military units who will "improve" the land around your cities, increasing the land's productivity or providing access to a nearby "resource." Improvements include farms, trading posts, lumber mills, quarries, mines, and more. During wartime your enemy may "pillage" (destroy) your improvements. Pillaged improvements are ineffective until a worker has "repaired" them.
[NEWLINE][TAB][TAB]"The absurd is the essential concept and the first truth."[NEWLINE][TAB][TAB] - Albert Camus [NEWLINE][TAB]
[NEWLINE][TAB][TAB]"The brain is like a muscle. When it is in use we feel very good. Understanding is joyous."[NEWLINE][TAB][TAB] - Carl Sagan[NEWLINE][TAB]

[NEWLINE][TAB][TAB]"The fate of unborn millions will now depend, under God, on the courage and conduct of this army. [...] We have, therefore, to resolve to conquer or die."[NEWLINE][TAB][TAB] - George Washington[NEWLINE][TAB]
[NEWLINE][TAB][TAB]"Every French soldier carries a marshal's baton in his knapsack."[NEWLINE][TAB][TAB] - Napoleon Bonaparte[NEWLINE][TAB]
[NEWLINE][TAB][TAB]"The physician can bury his mistakes, but the architect can only advise his client to plant vines."[NEWLINE][TAB][TAB] - Frank Lloyd Wright[NEWLINE][TAB]
[NEWLINE][TAB][TAB]"Numberless are the world's wonders, but none more wonderful than man."[NEWLINE][TAB][TAB] - Sophocles[NEWLINE][TAB]
[NEWLINE][TAB][TAB]"Honesty is the best policy."[NEWLINE][TAB][TAB] - Miguel de Cervantes[NEWLINE][TAB]
[NEWLINE][TAB][TAB]"Be not afraid of greatness: some are born great, some achieve greatness, and some have greatness thrust upon them."[NEWLINE][TAB][TAB] - William Shakespeare[NEWLINE][TAB]

[NEWLINE][TAB][TAB]"The true test of civilization is, not the census, nor the size of cities, nor the crops - no, but the kind of man the country turns out."[NEWLINE][TAB][TAB] - Ralph Waldo Emerson[NEWLINE][TAB]
[NEWLINE][TAB][TAB]"The city is the teacher of the man."[NEWLINE][TAB][TAB] - Simonides[NEWLINE][TAB]
[NEWLINE][TAB][TAB]"Stand your ground. Don't fire unless fired upon, but if they mean to have a war let it begin here!"[NEWLINE][TAB][TAB] - John Parker[NEWLINE][TAB]
[NEWLINE][TAB][TAB]"Seek not the life of the immortals, but enjoy to the full the resources that are within reach."[NEWLINE][TAB][TAB] - Pindar[NEWLINE][TAB]

[NEWLINE][TAB][TAB]"If I can in any way contribute to the diversion or improvement of the country in which I live, I shall leave it [â€¦] with the secret satisfaction of thinking that I have not lived in vain."[NEWLINE][TAB][TAB] - Joseph Addison[NEWLINE][TAB]

Resets the Advisor system so that all the Advisor messages will reappear.
Automated workers don't replace existing improvements.
Automated workers don't remove features Like Forests, Jungle, or Marshes except when improving a strategic or luxury resource.
Disables Reward Popups (Technology, Ancient Ruins, etc.).
Disables on-map Recommendations when Settlers or Workers are selected.

Condenses many game tooltips to just the raw information, removing explanatory help.
Enables auto-turn-cycling when in Multiplayer games.
Enables auto-turn-cycling when in Single Player games.
Enables quick combat resolution in multiplayer games.
Enables quick unit movement in multiplayer games.
Enables quick combat resolution in single player games.
Enables quick unit movement in single player games.

The largest number of autosaves kept before the game begins deleting old ones.
The game picks the interface size it believes fits your screen resolution best.
Forces the game to use the smaller version of the interface.
Strategic View will use higher texture resolution, allowing you to zoom in more. It is more taxing on your computer hardware.
The GPU will be used to decode compressed textures when appropriate.
Display the simple score list in single player games.
Display the simple score list in multiplayer games.
When zooming OUT, the camera will pull straight back instead of remaining anchored to the cursor.
All Policies will be displayed in the Social Policy Screen, regardless of Era and what branches have been unlocked.
You Must Restart For Changes To Take Effect
Minimize gray tiles seen while scrolling around the map. This can cause stuttering.
Allow shadows to fade out at far zooms. Improves performance at those zoom levels.
The game will remain in the loading screen until all of the terrain in the world is generated graphically.
Enables advanced culture borders. It is more taxing on your computer hardware.

The unit selection will advance to the next unit as soon as a command is given and will not wait for animations to complete.
Receive a Steam game invite when it is your turn in a Pitboss game. This notification only works if the game is played on the internet and you are Steam friends with the game host.

Saving a Map will save out the terrain data of the game you're currently playing in a format which can be read into the World Builder Tool. This allows you to have a template to work with when creating your own map, or to return to this specific map layout in a future game.
View all important messages which occurred during the game.
View various graphs of data collected for each player.
View the world map and the growth of territories over time.
Players are joining the game. Game is paused.
The game will randomly pick one of the map types for you to play (not Earth). You will not be told what was picked.
The game will match you with any of the map types (not Earth).
The game will randomly pick one of the map sizes for you to play. You will not be told what was picked.
The game will match you with any of the map sizes.
Leader is unavailable because some players do not have the required DLC package '{1_string}'.
Can not open save game.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]File may be corrupted or invalid.
The game will randomly pick one of the leaders for you to play.
A large region dominated by hills and mountain ranges.
A world almost completely covered in forest.
A world with regions of big continents and small islands.
A large region that is all tundra and well forested.
Less random than Continents, but you can control the number of continents.
A circular pangaea. You can choose what type of terrain is in the center.
A small world without oceans. Climates and resource appearance defy the laws of weather physics.
A very large world, dominated by hills and mountain ranges.
A region similar to the Great Plains of North America, but with random elements.
A world with two large, fairly balanced continents. Suitable for duel or two-teams multiplayer.
Each civilization gets its own subcontinent. All are connected to the arctic region at the center of the map.
A severely glaciated world where only regions near the equator are habitable.
An all-land region that has a large salt water sea in the center.
A world without oceans, only lesser bodies of water.
A world with numerous large islands, roughly equal in size but varying in terrain. Civs are placed on the best available islands.
A novelty map type played out on a maze made of land and sea lanes.
A world with regions of big continents and small islands.
A world where one half mirrors or reflects the other. Designed chiefly for multiplayer fun.
A fertile region bisected through the middle by a barren desert. Suitable for duel or two-teams multiplayer.
An oval-shaped pangaea with random bays carving in to the sides.
A world almost completely covered in jungle.
Each civilization gets its own subcontinent. All are connected in clockwise fashion to adjacent neighbors.
A balanced map designed for 2 players.
Extra small, land-heavy region, tailored especially for fast-paced multiplayer team games.
A very large world, similar to Earth, where all civilizations start on the continent akin to Asia-Europe-Africa.
A region split horizontally by desert.
A region split vertically down the middle by a wide channel of water.
This map is sectioned into 4 equal sections, separated by water, with land in the very middle.
A very large world, tilted on its side with its south pole always locked in to facing the sun.
Each civilization gets its own subcontinent. Both Hub and Ring style land bridges connect the areas.
A region similar to the Amazon Jungle of South America, but with random elements.
A region similar to the Mediterranean Ocean, but with random elements.
A region similar to the Polynesian Islands of the Pacific Ocean, but with random elements.
A region similar to the Rocky Mountains of North America, but with random elements.
A region similar to the Sahara Desert of Africa, but with random elements.
A region similar to Siberia in northern Asia, but with random elements.
A region similar to the South Pacific area, including Australia, southeast Asia and numerous islands.
An all-land region featuring a large crater lake in the middle.
All players start on one large landmass. There may be small islands off of the main continent.
The world will consist of a few large landmasses and some smaller islands.
The world will consist of a few medium landmasses and some smaller islands.
This world will consist of many islands.
This world will consist of many tiny islands.
A highly random map that will often form thin, snaky continents.
A map that spans the entire planet.
A map template will be chosen that supplies one continent per team (maximum of six, however).
A map template will be chosen that includes exactly two major continents.
A map template will be chosen that includes exactly three major continents.
A map template will be chosen that includes exactly four major continents.
A map template will be chosen that includes exactly five major continents.
A map template will be chosen that includes exactly six major continents.
Resources will obey the standard rules in the usual, logical manner.
Resources will be placed in irrational locations, such as Bananas in the snow.
Resources will be placed in irrational locations and there will be crazy amounts of some types.
Tectonic-style mountain ranges, along random fault lines.
Fractal-style mountain ranges: small, numerous and well scattered.
Fractal-style mountain ranges: medium, snaky and highly random.
Fractal-style mountain ranges: large, fat clusters, but fewer of them.
Numerous small and tiny lakes, well scattered across the map.
Larger lakes and some tiny oceans will appear.
Meandering rivers flow away from the central mountain range.
Large lakes or seas, with some rivers as well.
The only sources of fresh water are from oases in desert areas.
Most bodies of water will be salt water seas of modest dimension, highly randomized in shape.
Choose whether to add smaller landmasses in between the regions created for each civilization.
Choose not to add any extra land between civilizations.
Add extra land between civilizations. (Only available up to a maximum of ten civilizations.)
Peninsulas and bays are possible. This is the most randomized land shape.
Fewer, less intensive irregularities in the shape of the coast.
Each civilization's landmass will be a solid blob.
Bridges connecting subcontinents will be 2 plots wide.
Bridges connecting subcontinents will be 3 plots wide.
Bridges connecting subcontinents will be 4 plots wide.
Some hills and forest sprinkled across a vast grassland.
Small patches of mixed terrain sprinkled across a vast plain.
A lush forest sprinkled with grasslands.
An overgrown jungle sprinkled with hills and forest.
A vast desert sprinkled with hills! Water setting matters greatly.
A frigid landscape with only small pockets of more fertile plains.
Rugged highlands sprinkled with grassland valleys.
A standard climate, as if the map represents a whole world.

Open slots can be occupied by joining players.

Closed slots can not be used by players.
Select game options then host a game. This will create a game that players on you LAN will see in the lobby and be able to join.

You are the last remaining human player in the game.
The game has the maximum number of players.
Players take their turns at the same time.
Players take their turns in order.
Players take turns based on their war status.[NEWLINE]Warring human players take their turns sequentially.[NEWLINE]Non-warring players take their turns simultaneously.
